Award.AwardTitle: The Seventh IMACS International Conference on Nonlinear Evolution Equations and Wave Phenomena: Theory and Computation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports travel for participants in the Seventh International Association for Mathematics and Computers in Simulation (IMACS) Conference on Nonlinear Evolution Equations and Wave Phenomena: Computation and Theory," held 4-7 April 2011 at the University of Georgia. The workshop brings together researchers in theory, computation, and applications of models for nonlinear waves. The conference program, which includes tutorials suitable for students, is designed to be valuable for young researchers.

The workshop will enhance communication among junior and senior researchers in nonlinear evolution equations. Conference proceedings will be published. The conference encourages and supports participation by graduate students, junior researchers, and members of under-represented groups.

Conference web site: http://www.cs.uga.edu/~thiab/waves2011.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed conference focused on the derivation, theory, numerical simulation and application of nonlinear wave equations. The conference is designed to bring together researchers in theoretical and computational mathematics, the applied sciences and engineering.

229 research papers have been presented at the Conference. Participants from 36 countries that includes 68 international ones and 161 from USA were present. We had 41 graduate and undergraduate students, 3 junior faculty. In addition, out of the 229 participants, we had 27 women who attended the conference.

Participants have been selected based on their area of interest that is within the scope of the conference. Students, women, underrepresented groups and persons with disability are encouraged to participate and many are given financial assistant.

The conference was an excellent opportunity for interdisciplinary research and educational experience for all participants. The conference is international and designed for participation by faculty, postdocs, students and industry. This was very clear from the group of participants and the number of students attended this conference including undergraduates. Participants are very pleased with the quality of the conference and a good number of them asked me to organize it again.

Two well-known speakers gave Keynote talks on recent development in nonlinear waves and optical fiber communication systems.

One Tutorial was given to the students and interested participants. The tutorial was available to participants free of charge and it was well attended.

A Book of Abstracts was published and distributed to the participants during the conference.
